comments.commentBody: Though a some people will say that it was the right thing to do to maintain the UK's sovereignty, the veto was actually wielded to protect Britain's banks, i.e. the Conservative Party's paymasters.

Hindus have always cremated their dead. Originally, and even now, bodies were burned on a wooden pyre with more wood and incense and other air purificants. About 20 years ago, electric crematoriums came in. We took our mother, when she died, to one of these.

Yesterday, we took our dog Aloe, to a pet crematorium. Its the way to go, ecologically and otherwise.

Well "nl" we do have a national health care program. It's called Medicaid. It's already designed to give you exactly what Obamacare wants to give you. The absolute very basic care you need to stay alive. Why someone would want to remain alive when they know they are dying of something incurable is beyond my understanding. All they’re doing is making insurance companies pay out more money to hospital and clinics. Donate your diseased body to a research facility looking for cures and let everyone get on with their lives. Draw up a living will outlining you desires.

I really don't understand how getting cremated leads to the Hinduization of America or why it is pagan and/or why drag Hinduism and Paganism into this debate. Cremation is the best way to speed up the process of sending the body to its elemental self.  Isn't it a good thing that people are recognizing the soul is eternal and the body is impermanent.

Why do they have to send you the ashes?
With 98% gone to other patients, blood down the operating room drain, or up in smoke, why are the last 2% so special?
Nobody wants to simply say "That's not dad, he's gone."

That part struck me as wrong, too.
Hinduism is not anywhere in the discussion.
The main taboo disintegrated when the Pope endorsed cremation for all the dead during WWII. Just too much strain in Europe to try to embalm that many when people were homeless and suffering in other ways.

You are right. Saying it's less than embalming is not a valid comparison.
The comparison should be to how much to dispose of any other similar item, like a dead pony. I'm not trying to be silly. I think the funeral industry needs some competition from completely different backgrounds. Start from scratch with some think tankers who don't have their sales pitches to the grieving already memorized.
Some years ago I saw a cemetery advertisment offering "eternal care" of graves for $1000.  I was tempted to call and ask if for $500 I could have care for half of eternity.
I always hoped my ashes would wind up someplace nice like Timely Manor.

Be sure to call privately owned funeral homes. They seem to charge significantly less for cremations than the chains. Don't go by the name. The chains all kept the local, nice family funeral parlor name. You HAVE TO ask them who owns them and are they a chain. Also ask the church where the service is being held. They seem to know the lowest cost too.
A chain priced a cremation for a family member at over $4000. (The one the spouse jumped at without checking.) A superb locally owned funeral home conducted it for under $2000. Both used the same crematorium nearby.
I agree. I want to be cremated, but this is not because I am "spiritual" or Hindu! I simply don't care what happens to my body after I am dead. I do not believe in any post-asystole existence!

Not all Judeo-Christian religions demand burial. Catholic Churches, for example, do support cremations as well (and have since the '70's).

So you are correct, the bible does not demand burials.

You can donate your body to medical research or your organs for transplant and still request that you receive back any remains once those have been cremated (which is typically what they do once they have completed using the body for any research purposes).  This way you can still feel that your body is going to help the living, while also being able to honor the surviving relatives who may want to have the cremated remains for their own sense of closure, should they want to either scatter or inter those remains at a later time.

The AVERAGE (complete) funeral service is around $7500 (NOT 10-16K!) and MANY cremations also do have the same components to them (visitation, church service, graveside service/interment, etc) as a burial family--which means that often cremations are not that much cheaper than burials either (if a family chooses to have all of the same services as well).

The bottom line: as a family, you ONLY pay for those services that you choose! So if you choose a bronze $10,000 casket plus all of the services, with a ton of flowers, food for 100 people, etc--then yes, your bill will run between 10-16K or higher--but this is only if you select those kinds of products or services to begin with!

The BEST thing is to pre-plan for this expense by going down to your local funeral home and doing a pre-arrangement. You get to lock in today's prices so that if you die 40 years from now, you are still guaranteed to receive what you already selected (or the available equivalent). You then can have years to pay this off in small installments.

This is No different than opening up a 529 college savings plan for your kid's college expenses when they are still small that will also lock the same rate of tuition. It is called pre-planning for a reason.

This way you won't be saddling your loved ones with the extra expense. We are all going to die sometime, I don't understand the big deal in planning to pay a funeral expense ahead of time--I am sure my kids will sure appreciate my having done so!!

A few years ago, I met Stanley the Steamer Levey, a great jazz drummer who had recorded with your father back in the bebop days. He spoke VERY highly of Stan Getz, whom he admired greatly, and also Dizzy Gillespie, who is on some of those recordings. Stan Levey was a joyous and generous man, a real treasure as a musician and even more as a family man. Some of these old guys get to go on and on, and enrich everyone else's life every minute they are on this earth.

The rest of us, who are not nearly as intelligent or discerning as yourselves, are just going to lay back and hear some jazz, and thank God we- and Mr. Dunlop- are alive and kicking.

I'm going to order the CD, too, and when I listen to it, I'm going to remember why I read the Times, and be glad I got to hear this artist.

You captured it "all" Dan Barry! Thank you so much. I'll send you a copy of my documentary of tomorrow night's show when it's finished. Have a great holiday.
Buffalo's a wonderful city.  Just a little cold in the winter, a little isolated.  But, altogether, the people are a breath of fresh air.

Dear Dan Barry and NY Times Editors,

Thank you for this story. It shows many examples of what each of us can do to make part of this world. It ends on an up note. It is brave with the minor, the augmented, the diminished, and the major, all working together. It shows what each of us can do in our own way, in our own way, with what we each already have, as the who we each already is.

Sincerely,

Alex Linsker
"Collective Agency" Coordinating Council member
Portland Oregon
